utterances: (Soundbite of music)
(Soundbite of explosions)
(Soundbite of drum roll)
And now, the moment we've all been waiting for: Bob Mondello's worst film of the decade.
Bob, the worst film of the decade is?
Well, certainly the most annoying one is Mike Myers' ""The Love Guru.
(Soundbite of movie, ""The Love Guru"")
(As Guru Pitka) Is he Mr. Right or Mr. Right Now?
Rajneesh, let's make like a baby and head out.
The Love Guru"" is the story of a very needy guru who is played by what seems to be a very needy Mike Myers who is hired to motivate the Toronto Maple Leaves.
The hockey team.
His methods include lewd self-help mantras, elephant erotica and an endless supply of jokes about male endowment.
(Soundbite of movie, ""The Love Guru"")
(As Jane Bullard) Damn.
(As Prudence Roanoke) Damn.
(As Jacques Le Coq Grande) Damn.
(As Guru Pitka) Looks like he's smuggling a schnauzer.
It was so bad.
It was coarse and unpleasant.
Mike Myers is so full of himself in the picture.
I mean, he's almost winking at the camera.
He is smirking at his own jokes.
He makes you want to throttle him.
Oh, I - listen, he was...
You're breaking out in hives.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I am.
But you did sit through every last minute of all of these movies we've been talking about.
You're pretty resilient, Bob.
Yeah, I guess.
Listen, I've still got the best job in the world.
I see an awful lot more movies than most people, though, and a lot of them are not, shall we say, of the first water.
That's our film critic Bob Mondello.
He's been dropping by all month to talk about the decade gone by in the film world.
Bob, thank you so much.
It's been a lot of fun.
And I know those of you listening are dying to tell us your most hated films of the decade.
Join the conversation at npr.org, and while you're there, check out the arts podcast.
Bob's got more about the movies in theaters now.
That's at npr.org/movies.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Michele Norris.
In Beirut today, a bomb claimed the life of an anti-Syrian member of the Lebanese parliament, his son and at least eight other people.
The explosion struck along Beirut's waterfront, where ambulances rushed away victims.
(Soundbite of ambulance siren)
It is just the latest in a string of targeted killings stretching back to the assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri that took place two years ago.
Lebanese officials are calling the bombing the latest effort by Syria and its allies to destabilize the country.
NPR's Peter Kenyon joins us now and he's in Beirut.
Peter, what can you tell us about this attack and about the member of parliament, who, it seems, was the target?
Well, Michele, it hit very near the beach in Beirut's Manara neighborhood, next to a sporting club and an amusement park.
Investigators suspect it was a car bomb.
It was a powerful blast that shattered windows several hundred yards away up a hill.
And it set more than one car ablaze.
Among the dead, Walid Eido, he's a senior member of parliament from the Future Movement.
He's a close ally of the slain Prime Minister Rafik Hariri.
He was a man in his mid-60s, a former prosecutor and a judge, not a leading figure in Lebanese politics but an outspoken critic of serious influence.
He was killed along with his son, a pair of bodyguards and several other people.
Now, there've been five other explosions in the past month here, but this one is different in that it appear to target Mr. Eido.
The others occurred at night, relatively isolated areas.
They were seen as an attempt to scare people.
This one is a targeted killing and reminds people here of the bombings and attacks that struck a number of anti-Syrian figures since the Hariri assassination in 2005.
Has there been a claim of responsibility?
We have not heard one yet and officials say they actually aren't expecting one.
Government officials, including the Druze leader, Walid Jumblatt, have already blamed Syria and its allies inside Lebanon.
Jumblatt says Damascus is determined to destabilize the country because it continues to push for an international court in Hariri case.
Syrian officials have been implicated by U.N.
investigators in that killing, but Damascus denies any involvement.
Opposition leaders, including the head of the Hezbollah Shiite militia, are calling for calm and urging people not to rest their judgment.
And the Bush administration condemned the bombing as an act of terrorism.
State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said it was premature to single out Syria for blame, but he did say it was clearly the work of those who want to undermine Lebanese democracy.

Well, it does seem that this bombing comes in in an especially fragile time for Lebanon, with the army already engaged in battles in the north against Islamist militants and the opposition trying to topple the government.
How are people there in Lebanon responding?
Well, over the weeks, we've just seen the level of anxiety clearly rising.
Today, two more Lebanese soldiers killed north of Tripoli.
And that battle against the Fatah al-Islam militants in the Nahr al-Bared Camp is now on its fourth week.
The number of dead for the army is in its mid-60s.
There have also been reports now that more fighters and weapons crossing the border from Syria.
So tensions are high.
As always, there are several scenarios playing out at once.
And it's hard to keep track of all of them.

The apparent spread of al-Qaida-style Islamist ideology in the Palestinian camps here, the ongoing efforts by Hezbollah and other opposition parties to bring down Prime Minister Fouad Siniora's government, and this slow process of setting up the international court in Hariri case.
There's no sign that any of these crises are getting close to a resolution.
In the near term, that means another dismal summer for Lebanon's economy, especially the tourism sector.
In the longer term, people are wondering if their leaders can keep the situation from sliding into even worse violence.
Thank you, Peter.
You're welcome, Michele.
That was NPR's Peter Kenyon speaking to us from Beirut.
The plight of Iraqis like Aamer will be the subject of a hearing Tuesday by the Senate Subcommittee on Immigration, Border Security and Refugees.
Democratic Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts is the chairman.
There's a humanitarian crisis of extraordinary proportion and extraordinary need, particularly among those refugees that have been a part of friend of the American operation.
They all have a target on them, and they are not going to be given some kind of a sanctuary; they are going to be marked for death.
Congress has authorized a program that grants special immigrant status to 50 military translators a year from Iraq and Afghanistan.
Otherwise, Iraqi refugees must go through the State Department's resettlement program, which last year took in 202 Iraqis.
Senator Kennedy believes the U.S.
has a responsibility to do more.
We've been willing to accept 200 Iraqi refugees.
I don't think the United States can assume more than its capability, but I think we have to demonstrate a willingness for leadership, and that has not been the case.
Just how many Iraqi refugees the U.S.
will take in this year is an open question.
We have really not established a number.
The first thing that we need to do is to identify the most vulnerable, so that we have some idea of what the needs are.
